content:
The stub generator has error in it.
It should be:
loop H read row:string(10)
not
loop H read row:string(1)

Why was it approved?  All languages that allocate given length to string will malfunction with the default code.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Great puzzle overall, that may look hard in the beginning, but can be solved in a simple way that can teach participants to think simple. 

The description is a little bit hard to understand, but it shouldn't obstruct much

I don't know, it seems a little too easy. All you need are the corners.
It is a very interesting concept, and I'd love it if it were just a little harder!

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Very interesting. The statement is simple, they have many ways to solve it, but the proposed solution is easy.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Unique and Interesting

I like very much the idea, but i think i see a kind of workaround: If the 4 corners are "X", then square, if the 4 corner are "." or "/" or "\" then ellipse, else triangle.

For an easy puzzle it's okay, but this solution is missing the point and would work... maybe it would be possible to avoid it?

Your solution makes use of calculating the weight of the object, while the instructions do not hint that this would be possible.

Consider the following triangle
x...........................................................................................................
xxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxx
x...........................................................................................................

This has the ratio > 0.6427, so your solution would fail. 

My suggestion: remove the limts that make weighing possible, i.e. "Triangle. At least one edge is along the image edge," and allow for shapes like

..................
......x..........
....XXX.......
...XXXX......
..................

and provide a general solution.

Around test 18, you've added some cases where one of the "corners" is a slash "/" while the remaining corners are all "X". For example:

.XXXXX.
XXXXXXX
.XXXX/.

What's the thought process behind this? In geometry (in other words, not CG), what shape would we call this? I'm not sure I'd call it an ellipse.

This is a copy of my rejected https://www.codingame.com/contribute/view/1283207c08b23b778fdd1fee82c2cb246932
That one is considered too complex for a 5-min puzzle, so I copy it here as "classic easy".

That's intentional, and that tries to make this a "puzzle" for the problem solver.
The statement `c` said "All other characters means half-full.", and having a '/' here instead of '.' or 'X' make the shape having more precise size.
It's `like` a ellipse mapping to ascii grid. It obviously is not, but should be the best effort that an ellipse could map.

The intention of this puzzle is "one simple way to identify that 3 shapes: area", so the test data is constructed towards this: having precise area ratio.
And that's how this is "easy".
For a "general solution", I think you mean detection of edges etc. ? And that might be much harder. Should I remove the tag "Geometry"?
I'll try to add one use case of this solution.

Oh, I've just fixed it (before reading your message).

> Why was it approved?
The reviewing process has unfortunately always been kind of a joke...
Thanks a lot! Sorry that I missed the buffer concept.

It used to be that editing the already approved puzzles cleared the solutions that were not yet submitted. Maybe it is not this way any more, but I did not want to be the one who caused the grief  of the players :)
Updated the description, as well as the title.

That's just like a low-resolution image. Some of the pixels around the edge are interpolated, and it isn't always done symmetrically.
Maybe the left side is at 0.1 and the right side is at 0.8, e.g.
